review_title: Bloomsbury’s gym management is an absolute shambles.
pros:
- They support you 100% with pay during a pandemic
- They recruit friendly people to work with at lower levels in the company, for example receptionists, personal trainers and sales executives.
- They have nice gym members
- A good place to start off but after a while it’s a waste of time and money
cons:
*Company Issue*

• Pay 
- The Personal Training business model is almost like daylight robbery.
- The payment structure is based on session delivery which is fine, however taking up to 80% of pay is horrific.
- You earn around a minimum wage salary…NOT £40k as they state in their job descriptions.
- Paying back furlough meant an increase in Pt prices but no increase for PT pay…

*In-House Issues - Bloomsbury Gym*

• Terrible Management 
- The ones who get to the fitness manager position have had zero managerial experience, they have sold personal training packs or been there for over 5 years. 

• Favouritism 
- specifically new recruits are treated very differently from the others (which included myself and 2 others).
*For example; letting them train clients on shift but not others, having a private WhatsApp group with them, passing through sales leads from the email account and never the others, building their PT profiles to make them stand out more from the rest.

• No Professionalism
- speaking about confidential matters with new recruits like health reasons, why you’re not having a good day at work etc. and then those confidential conversations being let out to others…dating one of them…which is a conflict of interest because they got away with everything (like training clients on shift or not working weekends or not cleaning the gym properly…the list is endless)

• Unfair Treatment
- Telling others off for leaving the odd dumbbell in the wrong place at the end of a shift, but not the other two.
- Carrying out investigations of petty excuses to add pages to their files in order to put you in a firing line/to be pushed out.

• Lack of support
- Not being supported through the down times of PT and low member attendance during covid months.
- Not being supported after long term absence due to injury.
- Not being supported for the last 8 months of my employment…I had ZERO 121’s.

• Lack of Care
- I had knee injuries and I was still struggling to bend down up until February 2022 (9 months later), which he also investigated and gave me a written warning for, even though it was backed up by private doctor notes, evidence and MRI scans and also occupational health.
- Threatening behaviour from fitness manager

• Constructive Dismissal
- I was also investigated for training a client on shift, even though all other Pt’s did the exact same but I was the one to be punished…how is that fair in any right? I received a disciplinary for that and nobody else did which was extremely suspicious.
- I made a complaint about this and it all stopped…that is even more suspicious!

• Two-Faced Management
- Very cliquey/talking behind peoples backs type behaviour throughout certain managers.
- Those employees who ‘sucked up’ to managers got pushed forwards, those who have a back bone got left behind.
- Managers rude to members in person and behind their backs
- Managers rude and overly open about views of other employees in the club 
- Very corrupt from all areas of management, not professional in any way and just a big mess. 
- Fake personalities
- All very bizarre to be honest.

• High staff turnover
- No wonder so many PT’s have left and will continue to do so. 
- Duty managers treated like cleaners getting paid £1 more than a receptionist which is comical
- PT’s get paid less than cleaners for their shift hours which is also laughable…so when we do their job (as they have no cleaners) we do it for less!

cons: I read the reviews before starting here and it didn’t look pretty by any means but I thought I would give them the benefit of the doubt and make up my own mind. Straight from there pretentious and tedious application process you start to see exactly where people are coming from. The management simply think that you are there to do all the things that they are too good to do and that you are stupid enough to do it for half the pay. You will be working 12.5 hrs a day on the weekends with no breaks and yet these guys call themselves a charity but it’s all a smoke screen to cover up how stingy, disrectful and selfish they are. There processes are joke “clearly under paid and over worked themselves” to the point where they can’t even be bothered to send you your P45 as it doesn’t really benefit them. You will be a lifeguard, a receptionist, a barrister, a cleaner and cover all their breaks whilst taking responsibility for the whole club while the actual managers are tucked up in bed and your making near minimum wage. It’s terrible it really is and anyone reading this I would seriously reconsider as you would do well in this day and age to find worse and if you start to see the systemic pattern ask yourself is this really worth it?

pros:
This company attracts good people to work for them.

Relatively good benefits and perks.

Pay is relative to the industry we work in, not amazing but not bad either.
cons:
The good people who the company attracts never last due to the unrealistic targets and expectations that get put on them set by management.

You constantly feel like you're fighting against the company for your commission, it feels like its someones job at head office to try and take commission off you. Even if you hit your target if they can push your commission able sales below 90% of your target they take all of your commission off you. I've had to challenge head office multiple times to keep my commission.

Favoritism is a massive issue in this company, good employees are bullied out of their jobs if management aren't a personal fan almost as if higher management feel threatened purely because they're popular and could possibly show them up.

Its frowned upon to leave on time even if you've fulfilled your contracted hours even though they wont pay you for the overtime and just simply say "Take the time back" even though they know you never will be able to.

Quite high turnover of staff although that is an industry norm.

The "Health Club" mentality is a thing of the past and now they operate as a profit making club.

job_title: Contact Centre Administrator in Epsom, England
pros:
The most flexible position I have enjoyed, allowed to work from home and at times required. 
Working late nights until 8pm and Saturday just 8am-1pm the only unsociable side but not bad at all.
Very clever set up which allowed the homeworking.
Pay is competitive
cons:
Dealing with health insurance and physiotherapy needs, it is a very professional set up and training is sufficient in how to handle the queries. The system is only as good as it can be, but does not cater for any urgency. There is a lot of having to say 'no' to too many people.

They offer an advanced service for the more specialist treatments required and the treatment service is very good. However the contact service is embarrassing. Requests just to speak to case managers are a guaranteed no - they are never available. The admin team (person) extremely overworked and unavailable as well (although I believe this has now changed). For the high number of calls received it is extremely difficult to keep having to say 'no' to so many people, even in serious situations.

pros: Loved PT- great environment to be in

pros: Generally nice people, reasonably flexible on hours. I assume a degree of rule bending goes on everywhere, so perhaps its not so bad really. Generally nice facilities
cons: Poor organisation, frequent failure to adhere to regulations on breaks for lifeguards. Part time staff made to feel constantly on their 'final chance' although they always struggled to replace people who left. Very poor maintenance of facilities, everything is a 'bodge job'. I always felt bad for people who paid the membership fees. Depressingly low morale - if you were openly polite, helpful or engaging with customers other staff found it weird.

review_title: If your not clinical staff you don't matter at Wessex
pros: made some great friends, lovely team, everyone was always friendly around the hospital, food in the kitchen was always good and we had some lovely staff events eg family days and Christmas parties.
cons: Management across the hospital was awful, I was bullied by my manager and was told I was lying when any concerns were raised higher up, they didn't seem to care that I had the most knowledge in the whole department either and seemed to pay no attention to the fact that I was completely unhappy with the conditions. They also ignored the fact the whole team had become in happy. To make matters worse out department had been placed in a house outside the hospital, this was never cleaned properly and had wires and health and safety issues everywhere, I do believe that this has recently failed a health and safety inspection. I was also promoted doing considerably hirer level work with nearly no extra pay.

job_title: Duty Manager/Team Leader in Birmingham, England
pros: Great team atmosphere your colleagues are your allies and assets - treat them well and you'll get on just fine. But in a job like this where people aren't always working there for the love of the job it's important you remember to keep everyone motivated.
cons: Management can be poor at times and is offered when it is felt like it - rather than when it is needed. Asking for help is seen as a weakness and offering suggestions is seen, on occasion, as an attack.

review_title: A good stepping stone but definitely not a long-term career.
job_title: Health and Wellbeing Physiologist in London, England
pros:
The company funds an advanced professional diploma in health and wellbeing physiology. 
Quick progression (but poor salary)
Free gym membership.
Good clinical experience.
Good stepping stone into more recognised clinical roles.
cons:
Lack of admin time to complete work duties as well as diploma, expected to complete your diploma in your own time.
Discrepancies in pay for people working in the same position as each other .
Very limited CPD available to physiologists (apart from the diploma) unless you have been working for the company for over 2 years. 
You can be made to travel to different London sites every day, which is tiring and impacts morale.
If you leave the company within 3 years you have to pay back mandatory training such as ILS and Phlebotomy, which you cannot work without.
Senior management impose their authority on you.
No incentive or bonuses for hard working individuals/sites.

pros:

cons:
Poorly paid 
Lack of support 
Management are 'winging it'
Cliquey environment
Negative behaviors encouraged 
Position was made redundant and they gave little to no support during redundancy process- was made to apply for roles, had interviews- a few interviewers were more interested in wanting to know the 'goss' about my ex manager..  All 6  interviews had to be chased for a response after waiting a week or two past the given outcome date. All with no real feedback as to why I wasn't successful in getting role- and that was internal interviews! 

Redundancy is high at Nuffield and they might be a not for profit company but they certainly do not reinvest it into parts where its needed and you are seen as disposable.

They use the team Wellbeing but offer little to their staff.

Not worth the hassle!

pros: Perks at  work discounts, free healthcare
cons:
Restructures give unqualified staff roles they know nothing about and are not interested in  others have to pick up the slack with no  thanks!
Programme directors in corporate sites are very underhanded on 2 occasions in interviews  I have been told if they hired me they would feel like they were betraying my manager.
Senior managers don't want to act on concerns of 'shop floor' staff brought to their attention even if this info is given to them by a line manager they dismiss it saying unless the person comes to me directly I can't do anything about it.
You have people with little to no people skills as PD's and APD's ruining  future managers they are meant to be knowledgeable and role models and this isn't the case!
Pressure is  put on client services teams because other departments feel the CS team are their PA's.
Preferential treatment is given to certain staff if their face fits others are treated like the 'help'!

pros:
Reasonable training. 
Healthcare included.
Pleasant work environment.
cons:
Poor support.
Minimal response to concerns.
Shortsighted management policies.
Lack of concern over employee health despite Nuffield 'philosophy '.
Lack of consideration. 
Managers that I have had to deal with lack ability.

review_title: Some great people but terrible organisation
pros:
Some of the people are good
Weekend shifts are often enjoyable 
Not particularly difficult 
Great for a part time job
Free gym membership
cons:
Have to stand as a receptionist for 8 hours, not allowed chairs because it looks "unprofessional"

The communication and teamwork is terrible - things are always going wrong because of it and that means you have to pick up the pieces of someone else's mistake because members complain. 

Quite a toxic environment. People always talk about others behind their back but never confront them with their issues. - unprofessional environment. Very little support from management, only false support to make you feel like they care but they don't. 

Hours aren't ideal - either 6am start or 11pm finish. 

Understaffed which means some people have to work 7 days a week. Expected to work shifts without being asked if you are available or are happy to, and when you say no they get upset. Only reason they won't take on more staff is because they are too tight with their money.

review_title: Great company to work for, can't complain at all!
pros:
Free gym membership for employees!!!!
friends/family get gym membership for only £5 a month. 
Amazing facilities (gym, sauna, steam room, jacuzzi, swimming pool etc)
You can use a Nuffield gym anywhere else in UK for leisure or work as you can also transfer to other centres quite easily so I'm told
cons:
As a swimming teacher, it's based on clients so they can't give me a fixed salary so the contract is 0 hours one. This is however, quite normal for swimming teachers unless you work for a school so I can't really fault Nuffield too much on this.  

Salary is £16 per hour but it doesn't rise with progression or experience. Again tho this is quite normal unfortunately for swimming teaching in general as a profession.

review_title: Why its great to work for Nuffield
pros: I work as a HCA at Nuffield Hospital Haywards Heath and I love it!!! I work with a fantastic motivated team, who I look upon as my extended family, doing a job that I love, being led by a structured and very supportive management. I love providing patients with basic care, giving comfort or just reassuring them that they are doing great, listening with a genuine smile providing a little encouragement to those suffering more bleaker times, I love chatting with those that have no one else to talk to and just making a difference. Other than my children, nothing makes me smile more.
cons: My hourly rate is less than the hourly rate I earn't cleaning houses.  I've spent the last two years studying hard, while working, as a single parent to two daughters, to gain my NVQ 3 and my pay increased by approximately 18p per hour. I hate to admit, I felt crushed.

review_title: Poor Management and Lack of Resources
job_title: Junior Club Leader in Newbury, England
pros: My colleagues were very positive and I had very flexible working hours. The children I was in looking after were also a blessing and I recommend this for anyone with an early interest in childcare who is still at school/college.
cons: Management was far below the standard of any other job I have ever had. Everyone in a management role is there because of who they know rather than their ability. This means that there are not only underqualified people in high-up positions, but there is no whistleblowing - incidents which should have been formally dealt with were often dealt with informally or not at all and people in much lower positions were left to pick up the pieces.

review_title: Interesting and varied work in a friendly environment but lower than average pay and not much  scope for promotion.
pros: Benefits such as gym membership and medical insurance. Company pension scheme. Offer good training opportunities, offer funding for appropriate courses.  Free car parking.  Family feel to the hospitals, with close multidisciplinary links due to having all departments under one roof.  Nice environment to work in. Varied work, keeps things interesting.
cons: Not much opportunity for promotion, pay scale poor in comparison to NHS with no set increments.  Difficult liaising with NHS lead services such as social services, occupational therapy etc as seen as 'private sector', there's a 'us and them' sort of attitude.

pros: Nice place to work in general
cons: No proper checklist .the one in place for a week took about 10 mins to fill and check your own job a manager with no cleaning experience at cleaning and thinking a part time cleaner has the same time in which the part cleaner can do the same has the full time cleaner - after the build not getting proper clean done all full cleaning wasn't done - she dislike when someone spotted how dirty the changing rooms was and I was gonna scrub - the looks - any ways on the whole I had over 30 years of cleaning under my belt and never seen it badly run from the cleaning side of things -nit picking because I was always ready at 10 pm that's was the end of my shift when I seen the other cleaner suppose to leave at six but always see her on a 10am to 6pm shift leave early any way but I say thankyou for giving me a chance I did enjoy the cleaning side the manager side due to lack of the expreince was a let down

pros: As with all gyms and fitness centres, the team becomes very close and you are able to make some good friends. This is mainly due to the us vs. them attitude that working for such a top heavy organisation fosters (I find the term charity shouldnt apply to Nuffield Health, it seems this is merely to enable tax breaks).
cons: The pay is terrible. Having central London gyms run by employees on near-minimum wage is unacceptable. Fitness and well-being instructors must work 60-70+ hour weeks earning money through personal training to simply afford a decent living standard. We constantly received emails telling us how well the company was doing, but saw nothing ourselves in terms of pay increase

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Haywards Heath, England
pros:
Free health care 
Nice people on lower levels
cons:
Low pay 
Shocking higher management 
Unfair treatment 
Bullying & harassment 
Out of date systems which are totally inefficient 
Huge heath and safety concerns , very well covered up 
Out of date systems which are ineffective 
No clear managerial structure 
Not in any way a charity, except by name and 'tax purposes'
Un-impartial HR department 
Senior management have an "I'm boss so what I say is golden" attitude. With no interest in employee ideas or concerns 
Within 1 month in the role I witnessed 2 accounts of bullying from senior management and within 6 months in the 
Role I became the victim of such harassment 
No induction process 
No training and development opportunities

review_title: Poor place to work as a lifeguard
pros: Free membership for myself and partner.
cons: Minimum  pay. ; Lifeguard were often kept on pool side for up to 3 hours, which was against the rule for the RLSS which is 90 mins at any one time. For a 5 or 6 hours shift we had one 5 mins and one 20 mins break. However, during that 5 mins break they made us to do a pool test, which isn't really a break, but their logic is anytime away from the poolside counts as a break. There is very little opportunity for lifeguard to move on as well.

pros: The people. Such a great mix of people. From head office to the cleaners. Everyday is different, always something to do and learn. Great place for personal development with good support and encouragement. Company reinvests in staff constantly. Has a great plan in place for the public. Makes huge efforts to change lifestyles of members and staff for the better.
cons: Salary much better in management positions than when starting out although the they do have a better than minimum wage wage. Still not good for a London club for any person to be on less that £8p/hr, not in this financial climate. The company has to many processes and meetings about meetings. If we could just send and email or complete an online form and things would work just as fine then we should do that.

pros: Amazing colleagues. You also get free membership along with a plus one attached.
cons:
Very POOR commission structure, you have to hit 90% of your actual target to even get a penny but then its still not guaranteed as people can cancel their membership which means its deducted from your target! Example... 50 sales = 100% 40 sales = 90%
You hit 90% and 1 person cancels your at 39 sales! So all the hard work is wasted!

You get stores which are much better and are cheaper! So it makes your sales job harder as your competitors is yourself. 

The management team are very poor! And they just threaten you by saying you'll lose your job if target isnt always met.

They do not teach you any of the system, and its only a one day training course talking about the company and nothing about the product we are going to sale!

Overall I would not recommend the company... As they dont

job_title: Personal Trainer in Bishops Stortford, England
pros: Amazing members and clients, close to home, free gym membership
cons: Negative staff and management, poor pay, poor pt rate, really old gym equipment. Now I'm not saying all Nuffield are like this just the one i was at, management had no interest in helping their pt's progress further within the company. Failure to delivery 1-2-1 between pt's and Fitness manager to see what help they needed if any, no one able to help coach pt's further. I've never worked for a group of management that are so negative in all my years of working

pros: We get great benefits, aside from free membership there's a nuffield reward scheme which allows you to get WOW points or discounts when shopping. The staff have been friendly overall and I feel well trained for the job. I am given flexible hours so can pick my own working week which has also been an advantage. Overall the clientele are nice and co-operative.
cons: I personally don't want to go into sport or sales so there are few career advancements for me. As a receptionist the tasks can be a little repetitive as well however I imagine it is the same everywhere.

pros:
I've read some of the reviews on here, and felt important to add my own perspective from over 20 years service, working in different sites including the Central Office. 
I've worked and continue to work with great people. Felt part of a company that's always trying new things, but has continued to grow. I've been well supported in my career and have genuinally felt that decisions have been appear. It's not perfect, but i've yet to meet someone who has said that about any large company. although work is stretcjing, the work life balance is excellent.
cons: Don't stretch too thin and be everything to everyone, focus on what we can be best at.

review_title: Work experince on someone else’s paypacket
pros:
Good experince being part of experince’s multi dicplined team such as GPs.

Lots of clinical experince and working with lots of clients to practice clinical skills

Level 7 diploma in health and wellbeing physiology

Great CPD opportunities
cons:
Awful culture in corporate wellbeing/health and wellbeing department.
 
senior management lack the experince to lead to large team. 

See 5-6 clients a day, while running a clinic, managing a team including GPs. This is while being paid a salary that’s embarrassing.
Plan to work here for 2 years. Work hard, do as much CPD as you can. Enjoy the experince you gain working along side experienced medical team. Then plan your leave for nationally recognised qualifications. 

You might as well be a piece of equipment. Extensive travel and very long hours with awful pay. Think of this as continuing education that won’t cost you anything but least it will be free.

pros: looked after ,treated well good patient care,good team ,good pension and medical insurance .relaxed atmosphere ,no  backbiting ,nice colleagues that I work with ,good ward manager ,just like working for the Nuffield ,I wish I had started working for them years ago
cons: cant think of any at the moment ,uniforms aren't very good,prefer the old style ,too much paperwork sometimes not enough time to give to the patient ,short staffing

job_title: Management in Crawley, West Sussex, South East England, England
pros:
Free membership across the UK to any of their branches. 

I had a fantastic team of colleagues.
cons:
Consistently giving out promises of progression to staff and not acting upon it, you could see the impact the empty promises had; they have lost some GREAT assets to their team because of this.

Demotivated team, due to senior management. Senior management team is never going to be angels in the other employees eyes (in any business), however I think they had more than good reason to dislike those in the senior management team. 
I do not agree with the lack of empathy and respect given to there colleagues.

pros: Great characters in the team that created a nice work environment in some ways. Members were pivotal to the positive nature of each day. Certain teams had fantastic methods and strong individuals that supplied success.
cons: Very dysfunctional outfit. Understaffed, no training provided for team members in first-time roles, no real team-ethic to satisfy company objectives. Systems were not transparent and evident from higher management causing certain roles/teams to be overwhelmed.

pros:
The company has amazing schemes to aid their employees in working their way up the ranks and gaining more experience as well as qualifications.
A very inclusive, can-do attitude within the workplace
cons: The hours were sometimes difficult to cover (but I am a single mum, so it was more an issue of affordable childcare in out-of-hours times)

review_title: Good company to work for, if you do your job right
pros:
It allows and helps you to progress, and it looks after its employees. If you work hard, you WILL be rewarded. If you have passion in what you do, you can inspire others and the management sees it and praise when necessary, but most importantly, rewards you! 

Good benefits and you get free access to the gym!
cons:
When you work hard and people notice this, they will take advantage of you and you wake up with a huge workload. 

Training in some departments is not always the best. 

Sometimes you can see differences in how management treats favourite employees.

review_title: a good place to work if you want to work in the leisure industry
pros: They do try to develop you alot whilst you are the company. There are hundreds of different departments you can go into within the company as they own hospitals and clinics too. The facilities are prestige, and the customer service is great.  The city club itself is the best gym/health centre you will find in London.
cons: They do not pay you enough. If you are looking for and not too fussed about pay - this is a great place to work.

job_title: Management (Fitness Club Role) in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
When I started, I felt like a valued part of the team, was given training and sent on courses.

Whilst not the best benefits package, there's a free gym membership, high pension contribution and free healthcare packages.

There is opportunity to progress, plenty of different roles and training available within the company.
cons:
Got the feeling that there seems to be a culture of telling staff what they want to hear a lot of the times or saying that there's just no money to do anything. All this whilst other clubs in the area are getting new equipment and refurbishment.

Was in a management team where if you did the bare minimum you were left alone, if you did extra there was bland platitudes of thanks but then your workload would increase or you'd be expected to do it everytime. It was less about performance and more about who could you blame for the failures instead and what "buzz" words you could mention to make you look better in conference calls. 

My GM was very quick to discipline some staff and not others for reasons that are very trivial at times.

Distinct lack of budget for training staff which leaves teams woefully unprepared for situations and can lead to sometimes dangerous situations.

Internal academy training is a joke and needs hugely reworking as some of the mandatory units are pointless for a lot of staff - lifeguards and cleaners do not need to complete IT governance training at all is just one example. Having "Nuffield" courses instead of paying for industry-recognised qualifications is also ratehr dangerous way to as this opens the company up to all sorts of potential safety issues in the event of a future incident. Academy units are meant to be completed on the first (or as close to) week of work yet I found that almost none of the logins would work. This, again, lead to an overactive GM asking for disciplinary actions for incomplete training.

Seems like upper-levels cared more about memberships sales numbers than anything else, didn't seem to care what it took and no excuse was good enough which lead to many people being mislead into taking out contracts. This also meant that the attrition rate was appalling and people cancelling in droves when they find out new members are paying less than them.

Given I had a salaried role, I was expecting that I would have been able to get on with my own work but found that my hours were dictated by how much sales daily rigour I had to in order to "help out" so I ended up with no time to complete my other important work. Any time worked over, I was told to "take back" but it was never when it would be beneficial to me but rather when it was of no use. With constant cuts to staffing being asked for from above, more work was being done by less people.

Regularly worked over my allotted hours, week in week out, only to be told that I could use any owed time to deal with an urgent family matter.

Work life balance was awful towards the end.

Never got commission once - the structure is unrealistic and does not promote people to achieve to gain more commission but more out of fear of being disciplined. You can have hit your sales target (even over-achieve) and get nothing before someone defaults on their first DD payment and don't pay within a small window. SO you've done the hard work, got them to sign and sorted everything only for them to not be paid right, go into arrears and not be able to pay until their wage is sorted.

I can't speak to other clubs, but it felt like my GM was out of their depth and either not getting the support or couldn't handle the pressure.

job_title: Front of House in London, England
pros: Free gym membership,  friendly environment, lovely members, some flexibility in shifts. Can really feel like home with a good team.
cons:
Barely any progression available. Very inexperienced and poor management can change everything - and turnover is VERY high so this is common. All staff enjoy for 6 months, then leave. 
Staffing problems ultimately effect the daily running of the gym more than anything, makes everyone’s lives difficult. Minimum wage.

pros: I've Worked for the Nuffield a long time I was in Cambridge when they took over the Evelyn Hospital I had been there for over 25 Years. I Did Leave the Cambridge Nuffield for a short while  and worked up there Hssu in Papworth as a PTL but after 3 years wanted to come back to the Nuffield Cambridge and it has been great they are a very good company and there standards are very high and great team work by all staff keeps The Nuffield Brand the Best.
cons: NONE WHATS SO EVER ALL GOOD

pros:
I have been a cleaner for the last 6/7 years doing different types of cleaning and with several different companies, and Nuffield has been the best employer by far. 
Unless, you have been very lucky, as an experienced cleaner you will have known what is like to clean sectors that are too big and cover other workers sections when they’re off, receive unjustified criticism from aggressive bosses/supervisors. You will have had arguments with other cleaners over equipment that is broken down, but it is better than nothing, you will have come back to work after a holiday and all your stuff has been pilfered by desperate workers who have been waiting two weeks for an order to come in.   
  Those issues never arise at Nuffield as the equipment and cleaning materials is always on hand, very well organised and in plentiful supply. The training is thorough and done online in the workplace, for which you get paid. If you have difficulties with computers, the deputies will help you. The induction is one to one with the supervisor and again very thorough.  You work as part of a team so never feel out of your depth.
The standards are high but maintainable because they are consistent and kept on top of mostly.  There are checklists to be ticked and serve as reminders of what is outstanding. Time is limited after the members have left the club, so poolside can be hard and hot work but still manageable.  Staff wise, people are mostly polite and friendly. The same can be said for the members. However, it’s not Disneyland and not everyone is Mary Poppins but that’s life everywhere.
cons: Only part time hours available

pros:
- I worked here as a temporary worker and was made to feel at ease and included right away. 
- All staff are given fire safety, CPR training as well as constant online training exercises.
- Any overtime was paid or time in lieu was offered
cons: - I sometimes had to work longer hours as consultants would overrun on clinics and this was not taken into account in timetabling.

review_title: A great team to work with.
job_title: Healthcare Assistant in Royal Tunbridge Wells, England
pros: I started as a healthcare assistant 9 years ago with very little experience and in that time I have gained so much from a supportive, professional team of healthcare professionals, who are as keen to teach as I am to learn. Patient needs are at the heart of everything they do and it shows.
cons: There is a small core of contracted staff who work long hours and as a result accrue many hours as time off in lieu. This is almost impossible to take back and then becomes worthless.

review_title: The shortest and worst workplace ever!
job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Ealing, England
pros: Nice promises, but don't believe in their false statements at the job interview.
cons: The worst Health Club ever. The management treat employees and customers as disposable items. There is no heating in the whole club and   they don't even give contract for the employee. They forgot to pay salary at the end of the month and when they finally pay after 2 months, they deduct a huge amount to spend for their own well-being probably. They put you in the front of angry customers and you cannot ask for help and advice. You are on your own from the very first day without any proper training and induction.

job_title: Senior Sales Executive in London, England
pros: Free Membership, Private Healthcare, Perks at Work
cons:
Sales Commission amongst other things leaves a lot to be desired. Whilst Nuffield have a great ethos and vision they are trying to achieve the energy put into the customers need to be replicated to staff as we are the ones working tirelessly to give the customers what they need.

For such a short sales process (3 days)  a 2 month wait for commission I think is Ludicrous. As sales executives we are their to drive new business to attract new members. we are not account managers so if we do our job as sales executives we should be paid regardless. I actually don't work to earn commission anymore because I have lost faith in Nuffield and earning commission.  I work to hopefully progress and earn more money as that the only way I feel I can make more money which is sad. with 90+ million profit you would have thought Nuffield would look after their staff better but I am shocked when I hear what some peoples wages are compared to people who have been in the company for years and has a lot more responsibilities. this doesn't match employee contribution to the company which projects to us that we are just a number

job_title: Accounts Payable Clerk in Ipswich, England
pros: My supervisors and managers are fantastic to work for, the staff are friendly, the environment is great, the hours are flexible
cons: I am working as bank staff and I would love a permanent position.  The hourly rate is not OK but I could do with a little bit more

pros: Fellow employees are good people
cons:
I've worked for this club for the past 7 years and each year the PDR's (performance development reviews) come up and each year I've been given good/exceeding and yet you never receive a good pay increase. 

This year I've been given an insulting 3% increase and their reasoning is that I've "already had an increase this year" even though I actually changed departments so the starting basic was slightly higher as a DM, I'm now less that 30p per hour away from minimum wage.

pros: Training and leadership development is superb - never enough but you can't fault the effort the company puts in. The vision of Nuffield is ground breaking. The board of Nuffield has some good people , particularly the longer serving ones, they believe in people and why it's important to develop and retain them.
cons: Sometimes overdoes the drive for profit at the expense of its people.

pros:
Free Gym Membership 
Private Healthcare
cons:
No one treats you with respect
Incredibly hostile working environment across departments 
Matron even described staff as "two a penny" with little value 
No encouragement or congratulation of work only criticise
Very high turnover rate of employees which is well known
Extremely demoralising treatment and no opportunity for progression

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in London, England
pros: The work environment is positive and the team is very friendly.
cons: The communication between different departments is poor. They’re  are understaffed which puts a lot of pressure of the reception team.

review_title: Free Gym membership not enough to keep me
pros: Gym Mebership and employee health scheme. Mostly friendly staff.
cons: Work hours and the abusive anti staff TOIL system which adds days to a working month, because shifts 1-9pm ended from anytime after 6pm. Not our fault NH doesn't fill shifts to 8.30 pm! Left because my overtime was never returned. Overlap changes meant we lost breaks. My manager was overbearing in her new role, Managing staff who had come from far more responsible roles after retirement

job_title: Epsom Head Office in Epsom, England
pros:
Free gym. 
Steve Gray is a good person with time for everyone at every level.
cons:
The “period of change” has lasted years. Constant restructures.
Redundancies every year without fail.
No clear career progression routes. 
HR aren’t in the same building and difficult to get ahold of.
Hot desking. 
Bonuses only for senior leaders. 
Bitter, tense office environment with most staff resentful of lack of pay rises, progression and respect given to them.
Senior leaders do not respect lower level staff.
Male dominated “lad culture”.

job_title: Cafe Associate in Crawley, West Sussex, South East England, England
pros: Free membership, free coffee for staff working in the coffee shop, relaxed atmosphere most of the time
cons: Low payment, bad management and lack of structure; working atmosphere can degenerate into gossip and bullying behaviour; very young and unqualified people are given positions of duty managers; main policy of managers is to give complete power to the customer in the detriment of the employee; they make the customer the king regardless of their behaviour and disrespect the employee

review_title: High staff turnover and minimum wage
pros: Great product and service offering, however company direction taking more corporate route which leaves staff struggling to cope with long working hours, demanding tasks outside job scope and minimum wages.
cons: Hours of work are unmanageable due to high staff turnover, existing staff are constantly stretched to the limit. Lots of paperwork. Lots of demands outside of working hours. Unachieable targets set with no reward or recognition.

pros: Really friendly staff, let me work flexible hours and offered over time when requested. Rota was on a week to week basis and allowed to work around university. Free gym memebership.
cons: Poor pay. All Life guards on a zero hour contract so no holidays given. Rota often changes due to the rotational staff.

pros: For new PTs, it is a great place to learn the ropes and get experience. There are plenty of learning opportunities and you get a good scope of understanding for full body health, not just specifically fitness and weight loss.
cons: The pay structure is fine when you're starting out but once you have got to a certain point, it is a bit demotivating which explains why you have a fairly high turnover of PTs.

review_title: Please do a lot of research before you join
pros:
Gym membership.

Good benefit

Good location for surrey commuters.
cons: Some managers do not have management skills, keep bullying other colleagues, throw you under the bus which leads to a high turnover in Finance department. The firing of their previous CFO indicates the trouble they are facing financially and the negative company culture.

review_title: I hope things have improved! (worked in the Wellbeing division - gym)
pros:
The company has a unique offering compared to its competition.
Health benefit scheme.
Free national gym membership x 2.
Friends and family discount.
At the branch I worked for I had a great line manager and colleagues.
cons:
Poor employee engagement, compensation and reward structures.
Staff retention strategy, inexistent!
Slow career progression.

review_title: Motivated Staff and atmosphere, willing to work again, good chance to meet new people
pros: I advice you to work there as they have a qualified management, motivated staff.
cons: The scheduling was my only problem. However, I sat wit the management I this issue been solved

pros: Big business, always new projects to work on, friendly atmosphere around the whole country and employees are valued.
cons: Can be issues that are only addressed after an issue arises in that area, not quick enough to solve the root cause of some system issues. Company can also refrain from 'upskilling' some employees.

pros:
Free gym
Flexible working
Nice office
Can add family/friend to membership for a small fee
cons:
My role was a new role for the business. I was made redundant after a year, so I seriously implore anyone who is thinking of going to work for this company (I can only speak for the head office) to understand that you are taking a risk - this company will not have your back, every decision that is made is made without consideration to anyone except the senior management.

Because of the blatant greediness of senior management/investors (please do not take any bearing to the charity aspect of this company, this is not a charity and it could not be any more capitalist and corporate if it tried) this has made the entire company environment negative and distrustful (and rightly so).

I was in a job that started off with no guidance from an inexperienced Manager (I would go weeks without hearing from them). There was already a negative feeling in the air from the recent redundancies at the time. See my breakdown below:

- Job role was not defined and no help from manager to define that, left me to my own devices
- Due to the lack of care in my development and history of redundancies, I started to push for senior management to define my role and responsibilities
- Had lots of meetings about this (nothing significant ever came out of them), although my line management changed about 4 times at least
- Agreed with a diff head of dept that I would work couple of days a week with them as they had space on their team and needed the help - was told that I would be reviewed after 3 months which never happened, they just carried on using me
- After a year was told my role was going to be made redundant, and no mention of my performance on the other dept I worked in
- No defined structure in teams and a lazy attitude to work, meant no one really took accountability and nothing got done - honestly, if you're looking for a place to grow and develop, this is not the place for you
- Avoid like the plague unless you like the risk (of being made redundant) and do not care about career/personal development, and do not mind being in a negative, unprofessional, unkind and un-collaborative environment
- Sexist, male dominated vibe in the Head Office

job_title: Client Services Administrator in London, England
pros:
Corporate Branch

- friendly staff

- not too stressful of a job
- weekends off
cons:
- can be clicky
- few issues with management around accountability and methods of discipline

review_title: Big Corporate Conglomerate Feeding the Big Man at the Top!
pros: Free gym membership for staff.
cons: Undervalued and poorly paid staff. Want a premium service but offer minimum wage - same as budget gyms.  No investment in staff.  Unobtainable targets. Demotivating managers up the hierarchy.  Targets set and then increased to help people higher up obtain obscene bonuses.

review_title: Great learning and making positive impact
pros:
Supportive line manager

Great team

Good location 
Competitive benefit package
Friendly working environment 
Supportive HR team to resolve queries
cons:

job_title: Health and Wellbeing Physiologist in Leeds, England
pros: Good on the job training, further education
cons:
The company culture is very bad.  Nuffield prides itself as a non-for profit but through my 3 years of working there I saw many times customer service and patient care compromised in the sake of profits. 

I would regularly see patients who would have been send to me to have inappropriate tests and assessments which the bookings and referrals team would tell them they need. Sadly after the hefty bill for services the patients still don't have the answers they need. 

Additionally Nuffield uses their staff like profit machines, and in my 3 years I saw many good staff members come and go, as they were poorly treated and over worked to see as many patients as possible. 

As a result the quality of care they gave would quickly diminish and they would end up leaving only to be replaced by new and much less experienced staff only for the cycle to repeat. 

Even staff members who worked in the high-end, high profit centres located in London were payed the same as centres throughout the country that saw less patients and made less money. This type of imbalance and their failure to correct it is one of the main reasons I left.  Additionally Nuffield management wouldn't let its team members in Physiology join a union, even to point that when I tried to join some they said they didn't recognise any of the unions, which was clearly intended to reduce the employee's rights.

Overall I did learn a lot from Nuffield and it got me to where I am today, but it was not without it's sacrifices and a lot of pain. If you are considering joining nuffield I'd tell you do do as much research as you can and try and speak to people in your profession before you join, don't believe everything the marketing and HR team tell you.

job_title: Client Services Administrator in London, England
pros: Gym membership, gym membership, gym membership
cons:
This company is the worst place I have ever worked for. I  was with this company just under two years and in that time I received the worst treatment. They overwork you, the hours are ridiculous, they have favoritism, they treat you like a slave.

The front of house does everything whilst the managers sit back and do nothing. We lost so many potential memberships due to the managers unwilling to do a tour of the gym and arguing over what shifts they want.

I worked very hard at that place and whenever I fell behind on my workload, rather than pull up the people that had been working with them for years and had gotten lazy, I was the one that got called upon. 

In my last 6 months I saw 9 people leave, consisting of the whole reception team and a few managers. Just before I left we had 3 new reception girls. One left after one month and the other two left 2 month's after I had gone. 

When I first started one of the managers that oversees the operation of 3 sites did not acknowledge me at all until my colleague had introduced us, in which his response was " yes I know who she is".

The gym itself was nice but, the changing facilities was disgusting. From the very day I started they had flies in the shower and up until I left they was still receiving complaints of this issue. 

The lockers in the changing rooms were broken into constantly.stolen constantly. I worked in one of the branches in Canary Wharf so you can imagine what was stolen from people's lockers. 

For a company that promotes health and well being, they are way of mark.

I wouldn't advise anyone that values their health and mental well being working for this company. I was emotionally distressed working for this place and I have former colleagues that I am still in contact with that have suffered emotionally.
